page.title: 19Local Airfields
page.content: There was a small airfield near Apsley Farm during and after the first World War, and a present member of West Chiltington W.I. well remembers being taken there by her father to see Sir Alan Cobham's Flying Circus, and to have her first flight in a tiny plane. A little farther north, to the east of Coolham crossroads, a larger airfield was used in World War II to give home- coming planes an emergency landing area. Barracks were built alongside the B.2139. The local farmers still sometimes turn up live ammunition, and the remains of a crashed plane lie buried deep in a nearby wood. Arun Feeds, a small agricultural manufacturing concern on the road to Shipley from Hungerhill, was built in the mid-1930s by the Milk Marketing Board, for drying and using grass from this airfield, for cattlefeed.
